TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS:  Very-fine, mixed, subactive, isothermic Typic Haplohumults

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Maricao clay--naturalized pastureland (Colors are for moist soil).
Ap--0 to 5 inches; reddish brown (5YR 4/4) clay; weak fine and medium subangular blocky structure parting to moderate medium granular; firm; slightly sticky, plastic; many fine roots; few distinct irregular-shaped aggregates of red (2.5YR 5/8) clay from the underlying horizon; very strongly acid; clear smooth boundary. (2 to 7 inches thick)
Bt--5 to 14 inches; red (2.5YR 5/8) clay; weak medium subangular blocky structure; firm; slightly sticky, plastic; common fine roots; common fine and medium faint light red (2.5YR 6/8) and common fine medium distinct yellowish red (5YR 5/8) masses; few faint clay films on face of peds; about 2 percent, by volume, pebbles; about 10 percent, by volume, saprolite; very strongly acid; clear wavy boundary. (6 to 24 inches thick)
BC--14 to 20 inches; red (2.5YR 5/8) clay; weak fine subangular blocky structure; friable; slightly sticky, plastic; few fine roots; about 40 percent, by volume, saprolite; very strongly acid; clear wavy boundary. (5 to 14 inches thick)
C--20 to 65 inches; 20 percent red (2.5YR 5/8), 20 percent reddish brown (2.5YR 4/4), 20 percent yellowish red (5YR 5/6), 20 percent dark brown (10YR 3/3) and 20 percent yellow (10YR 7/6) variegated saprolite having a red (2.5YR 5/8) crushed color and silty clay loam texture; massive; friable; nonsticky, slightly plastic; colors are indicative of parent material and are not redoximorphic features; very strongly acid.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Maricao, Puerto Rico.  Approximately 5.7 miles southeast of the town of Maricao from the intersection of P.R. Hwy. 105 and P.R. Hwy. 357, about 700 meters southwest of P.R. Hwy. 105 from kilometer marker 44.5 on dirt road, and 25 meters west of dirt road in naturalized pastureland; USGS Maricao topographic quadrangle (1960); lat. 18 degrees 09 minutes 24 seconds N.; long. 66 degrees 53 minutes 56 seconds W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Solum thickness range from 15 to 45 inches.  Depth to semi-consolidated lava, mudstone or tuff is more than 60 inches.  Reaction ranges from extremely acid to strongly acid in the A and AB horizons and from very strongly acid to strongly acid in the Bt, BC, and C horizons.  The combined total of rock fragments in the control section is less than 5 percent, by volume.
The A or Ap horizon has hue of 2.5YR to 7.5YR, value of 3 to 5, and chroma of 3 to 6.  Texture is clay loam or clay.
The AB horizon, where present, has hue of 5YR or 7.5YR, value of 3 or 4, and chroma of 4.  Texture is clay loam or clay.
The Bt horizon has hue of 2.5YR or 5YR, value of 3 to 5, and chroma of 3 to 8.  Content of saprolite ranges from 5 to 20 percent, by volume.  Texture is clay.
The BC horizon, where present, has hue of 2.5YR to 7.5YR, value of 4 or 5, and chroma of 4 to 8. Content of saprolite ranges from 20 to 60 percent, by volume.  Texture is silty clay or clay.
The C horizon is composed of saprolite, has no dominant color, and is multicolored in shades of red, brown and yellow.  Texture is silty clay loam or silty clay.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  The Agueybana (T) series is the only known soil in the same family.  Agueybana (T) soils are on similar positions but have thinner solums.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Maricao soils are on summits and side slopes of mountains of the Humid Mountains and Valleys MLRA at elevations of 800 meters or higher. Slopes range from 20 to 90 percent.  They formed in residuum that weathered from basalt bedrock.  The climate is humid tropical.  The average annual precipitation range from 56 to 109 inches and the average annual temperature range from 69 to 73 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the competing Agueybana (T) series and the Ciales, Cuchillas, Los Guineos, Picacho, and Yunque series.  The poorly drained Ciales soils are on lower concave positions, have fine-loamy control sections, and have a Histic epipedon.  Cuchillas soils are on similar positions, do not have an argillic horizon, have less clay in the control section, and are moderately deep to volcanic rock.  Los Guineos and the moderately well drained Yunque soils are on similar positions, have yellow kaolinitic control sections, and are Oxisols.  The somewhat poorly drained Picacho soils are on similar positions in concave areas, have fine-loamy control sections, and cambic horizons.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; moderate permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Most areas of Maricao soils are used for naturalized pastureland, forestland, bananas, coffee, and plantains.  The vegetation consists of native and introduced grasses, shrubs, and trees.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Summits and side slopes of mountains of Puerto Rico. The series is moderate extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE:  Raleigh, North Carolina.

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Ponce Soil Survey Area, Puerto Rico; 1971.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon:
Ochric epipedon - the zone from 0 to 5 inches (Ap horizon).
Argillic horizon - the zone from 5 to 20 inches (Bt and BC horizons).
The classification was updated with the 07/2005 draft from:  Fine, mixed, subactive, isothermic Inceptic Hapludults to:  Very-fine, mixed, subactive, isothermic Typic Haplohumults.
ADDITIONAL DATA:  Characterization pedon - Yauco Municipality, Puerto Rico; S01PR-153-004.  Sample by NSSL, Lincoln, NE., 03/01.
Maricao soils are in MLRA 270.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
